content: Prior to 1996, health insurance coverage for mental illness was historically less generous than for physical illnesses, with lower limits, fewer covered services, and higher cost sharing. Mental health parity laws aim to equalize coverage for mental health services with medical and surgical benefits. Prior to 1996, health insurance coverage for mental illness was historically less generous than for physical illnesses, with lower limits, fewer covered services, and higher cost sharing. Mental health parity laws aim to equalize coverage for mental health services with medical and surgical benefits. Policymakers have developed three general approaches to achieving parity: mandated coverage, parity coverage, and full parity approach. Federal mental health parity law prior to the ACA employed a mandated offering parity approach. The ACA expands federal mental health parity requirements and mandates coverage of certain mental health and substance abuse disorder services in specific financing arrangements. It does not include a comprehensive coverage mandate for mental health services at the federal level, but contains separate provisions mandating coverage for certain plans. MHPA was the first federal mental health parity law, employing a mandated offering parity approach with no coverage mandates but requiring partial parity. The MHPA (P.L. 104-204) was the first federal mental health parity law, mandating that annual and lifetime dollar limits on mental health coverage be no less than those for medical services. It amends ERISA, PHSA, and IRC to apply parity coverage requirements to all group health plans. MHPA establishes a small employer exemption and a cost exemption, further amended by MHPAEA.
